etymologies: Middle English (also in the sense ‘suit, befit, be appropriate’): from Old Norse sœma ‘to honor’, from sœmr ‘fitting’

definitions: give the impression or sensation of being something or having a particular quality

examples.text: there seems to be plenty to eat
it seemed that he was determined to oppose her

shortDefinitions: give impression or sensation of being something or having particular quality

definitions: used to make a statement or description of one's thoughts, feelings, or actions less assertive or forceful

examples.text: I seem to remember giving you very precise instructions

shortDefinitions: used to make statement or description of one's thoughts

definitions: be unable to do something, despite having tried

examples.text: he couldn't seem to remember his lines

shortDefinitions: be unable to do something, despite having tried

definitions: used to suggest in a cautious, guarded, or polite way that something is true or a fact

examples.text: it would seem that he has been fooling us all

shortDefinitions: used to suggest in cautious, guarded, or polite way that something is true or fact
